Title: Prove that the set of $n$-by-$n$ real matrices with positive determinant is connected
Content: Math people: In the fourth edition of Strang's "Linear Algebra and its Applications", page 230, he poses the following problem (I have changed his wording): show that if $A \in \mathbf{R}^{n \times n}$ with $\det(A) >0$, then there exists a continuous function $f:[0,1] \to \mathbf{R}^{n \times n}$ with $f(0) = I$, $f(1) = A$, and $\det(f(t)) > 0$ for all $t \in [0,1]$.  He says "the problem is not so easy, and solutions are welcomed by the author" (direct quote from the book).  Since the author welcomes solutions, I am not 100% sure even he has solved it.  Does anyone know if this is true or false, and may I have a solution or a hint?  I assigned this problem to a graduate student in a linear algebra class, because I wanted to give him a challenge.  Neither one of us has solved it.  I have a lot of other things to do, but I'd like to give him a hint. STEFAN (Stack Exchange FAN)
